meaning_mnemonic:
If you have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>thousand</kanji>, you have... <vocabulary>one thousand</vocabulary>.

Simply saying 千 is the most common way to say 1,000, but sometimes you might use 一千 to emphasize or clarify the exact number.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When it's used as a prefix, it takes on the related meaning of <vocabulary>ex-</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>former</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means <kanji>cut</kanji> so this generally means that something is cut. Something breaks or snaps. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be cut</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to snap</vocabulary>. Another meaning of this verb is <vocabulary>to expire</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>. This could be various things like your passport, or a deadline for an assignment.

You have <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> <kanji>letters</kanji>. What do you think these are? THAT WOULD HAVE TO BE <vocabulary>UPPERCASE LETTERS</vocabulary>, RIGHT? Whoops, sorry, caps lock was on for a moment, there.

You feel your <kanji>ear</kanji> getting… <kanji>hit</kanji>? This is the feeling of a <vocabulary>whisper in</vocabulary> your <vocabulary>ear</vocabulary>; perhaps a secret, or some other confidential tidbit of information. Whatever it is it has impact, which is why it feels like a hit!

Note that this word is more often used in writing than in casual speech.

You’ve already learned 仕方, which you know means "method" or "way of doing." When you don’t (that’s the がない part) have a way of doing or achieving something, you could say it can’t be helped, it’s no use, or there’s no other way. Makes sense, right? This is a popular phrase in Japanese, so we're sure you'll encounter it a lot!

A <kanji>substitute</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is a <vocabulary>substitution</vocabulary>.

Note that this word has a slightly formal feel to it.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>copy</kanji>, but what is a copy? It's basically a photograph, which is why this word means <vocabulary>to be in a photograph</vocabulary>. 

In other words, this is the word you use when you point at a photo and say, "hey, I'm in this!" You know it means "to be in a photograph" because every time you appear in a photo, you're doing something <reading>ru</reading>de (る), like sticking your tongue out or giving someone the finger.

The meaning of this word is pretty strange, having very little to do with the kanji meaning you learned. This word means <vocabulary>to carry something out</vocabulary>. Maybe you can think of it like someone is saying "<reading>You</reading> (う) <kanji>go</kanji> do that task!" to get yourself <vocabulary>to carry out</vocabulary> the task. Whatever you do, just know this is a weird exception word, so you may have to do some extra work to remember it.

<kanji>Writing</kanji> has <kanji>change</kanji>d our entire <vocabulary>culture</vocabulary>. In fact, when someone reads a good piece of writing it changes them, and changes their culture too. What writing has changed you so much it has changed your culture and the way you act?
<kanji>Below</kanji> the <kanji>ground</kanji> is <vocabulary>underground</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>soil</kanji> of the <kanji>earth</kanji> is the portion of the earth that is made up of <vocabulary>land</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>diagram</kanji> of the <kanji>earth</kanji>. What could that be other than a <vocabulary>map</vocabulary>?
Don't use one hand when you can use <vocabulary>both hands</vocabulary>. This is simply <kanji>both</kanji> plus <kanji>hand</kanji> put together. It can also mean <vocabulary>both arms</vocabulary>.

Kanji doesn't go together much better than this. <kanji>Both</kanji> plus <kanji>day</kanji> equals <vocabulary>both days</vocabulary>.

This is a bit of a formal word though, you'll hear important people say it more than your friends.

Here you have <kanji>both</kanji> <kanji>direction</kanji>s / <kanji>way</kanji>s. Every time you have to choose between something it's like having to choose between two ways. That's why this word is simply <vocabulary>both</vocabulary>. 

Close to the kanji is the meaning <vocabulary>both sides</vocabulary>, as well. Learn either for 両方, they're pretty similar.
This has a little hiragana attached to it but nothing that suggests it's a verb or an adjective. That means you can assume this word has the same meaning as its parent kanji.

When you put <kanji>all</kanji> your <kanji>power</kanji> into something, you're putting your <vocabulary>full effort</vocabulary> into it. Hopefully that's what you put into your kanji learning as well!
You know 日本 means "Japan." So, now you have the kanji for <kanji>all</kanji> added to it, making this word <vocabulary>All Japan</vocabulary> (as in "All Japan Railways" or something like that).
When you are <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>relax</kanji>ed you are finally <vocabulary>safe</vocabulary> and in <vocabulary>safety</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>direction</kanji> <kanji>yonder</kanji> over there is still just the <vocabulary>direction</vocabulary> of something, though a complicated way to say it, I think. This direction is the "what direction did he go in?" sort of direction.

This is a single kanji with an い at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. One of the meanings of 安 is <kanji>cheap</kanji>, so this is just that as an adjective, <vocabulary>cheap</vocabulary>. Time to go to a 100円 shop and get some 安い goods, ammiright?

When your <kanji>heart</kanji> is <kanji>relax</kanji>ed, how do you feel? What if this is after something startling happens? You would feel <vocabulary>relief</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>peace of mind</vocabulary>.
When you're <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>relax</kanji>ed, what do you feel? <vocabulary>Uneasiness</vocabulary> is what you'd feel.

Something is <kanji>flat</kanji> and <kanji>relax</kanji>ed. That is you. What words does that describe? To me, that would be <vocabulary>peace</vocabulary>. Just imagine something that is flat and relaxed, like a field of grass with happy people in it. It's so <vocabulary>peaceful</vocabulary>!

This is the way you write the <vocabulary>Heian</vocabulary> period of Japanese history, which is probably where you'll see this word the most.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>nine</kanji> <kanji>states</kanji>. This refers to a section of Japan from a long time ago that was presumably made up of nine states. Now it's just one big island, though, and that island is <vocabulary>Kyuushuu</vocabulary>. Go take a look at a map and find this giant island, it's a cool part of Japan!

You have your <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>state</kanji>. For Japan (since this is a Japanese word), that would be the main island, the big one in the middle: <vocabulary>Honshu</vocabulary>. You'll have to know some minor Japanese geography for this. Go look at a map of Japan and study it over real quick to see where I'm talking about if you don't know already.

This almost shares the meaning with the kanji. It's essentially the same thing, though when it's alone it refers to a specific <vocabulary>piece of music</vocabulary> (aka a <vocabulary>tune</vocabulary>).
<kanji>Famous</kanji> <kanji>music</kanji> is <vocabulary>famous music</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>have</kanji>, so this verb version means <vocabulary>to have</vocabulary>. An alternative meaning is <vocabulary>to exist</vocabulary>, because having something means that it exists for you.

The kanji isn't used too often for this word, so just use the kana when you write it. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes, so it's important to be able to recognize it!
When you <kanji>have</kanji> a <kanji>name</kanji> (that is known to people) or you <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>famous</kanji>ness, you are probably someone who is <vocabulary>famous</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>death</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to die</vocabulary>.
The kanji for <kanji>death</kanji> and <kanji>body</kanji> put together make for a <vocabulary>dead body</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have to use or see this vocab too much.
<kanji>Death</kanji> and <kanji>deceased</kanji>. That's a lot of death. This is <vocabulary>mortality</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well — <vocabulary>sheep</vocabulary>!

羊 can also mean <vocabulary>ram</vocabulary> in some contexts. After all, a ram is just a male sheep.
A <kanji>sheep</kanji>'s <kanji>fur</kanji> is <vocabulary>wool</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
When the thing that is <kanji>exit</kanji>ing is <kanji>blood</kanji>, you are probably <vocabulary>bleeding</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji>... who could that be? Let's think about it. Who invented kanji and therefore probably thinks they're the middle of the world? Who also is just a huge country that ruled much of Asia? That would be none other than <vocabulary>China</vocabulary>.

This is <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji>. Where is that? Probably just in <vocabulary>heaven</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>paradise</vocabulary>.

天国 is the general term for heaven. Depending on the context, it can also figuratively refer to any place that feels heavenly.
When something involves <kanji>all</kanji> the <kanji>country</kanji> you know it's <vocabulary>nationwide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>national</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is another section of Japan. It's quite nice, too. Look on a map and try to find it. So, the meaning of this word is also the reading, which you should be able to figure out because it's all on'yomi: <vocabulary>Shikoku</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is one outside of your own country. That is a <vocabulary>foreign country</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>other countries</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>overseas</vocabulary>.

You know 外人 the word that means "foreigner," but that word is a bit informal and can come off as rude. The nicer, more politically correct version of the word is the one above. An <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>. To differentiate this from "foreigner" we're going to use the more polite English version of this word as well (just like in Japanese): <vocabulary>Foreign Person</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Rice</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is the <vocabulary>United States</vocabulary>, otherwise known as <vocabulary>America</vocabulary>. Maybe they call it that because of all the rolling plains in the middle of the country? You could grow a lot of rice out there.

米国 is a more formal written term for the <vocabulary>USA</vocabulary>. You'll see it in news articles and official documents, but in everyday speech people usually say アメリカ.
Your <kanji>older sister</kanji> and your <kanji>younger sister</kanji>. These are your <vocabulary>sisters</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The お makes the word more polite. You're elevating the "<vocabulary>older sister</vocabulary>" title because you're a good younger sibling. Otherwise, the meaning of this word is the same as the kanji - just the feeling is different. You can also use this word to refer to a youthful-looking woman that you don't know, as in "Excuse me <vocabulary>miss</vocabulary>!"
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>walk</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to walk</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>long</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>long</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>leader</kanji> is the <vocabulary>company president</vocabulary>. Be sure to greet your 社長 with a hearty good morning when they stumble in!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You have something that's <kanji>before</kanji> (or in <kanji>front</kanji> of) <kanji>noon</kanji>. What is before noon? That is <vocabulary>AM</vocabulary>.

The hiragana attached to this word doesn't suggest it's a verb or an adjective, so we can assume it's a noun. While 後で (you may or may not have seen this word yet) means "after," this one means all the other meanings you learned with the kanji: <vocabulary>behind</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>back</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>rear</vocabulary>. Think of the ろ as a hint. It's like saying you're on the "road" (ろ) and you're driving so fast you're leaving everything "behind."

This shares one of the meanings you learned for the kanji: <vocabulary>after</vocabulary>. You can differentiate this one from 後ろ (which you may or may not have seen yet) thanks to the で on the end. Some people believe that after something's dead (で), it goes to an afterlife.
What is <kanji>noon</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji>? That is <vocabulary>PM</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>afternoon</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>think</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to think</vocabulary>.
When you have <kanji>life</kanji> and are <kanji>lively</kanji> that right there is true <vocabulary>life</vocabulary>. What is your 生活 like? Do you live?

The <kanji>outside</kanji> of the <kanji>sea</kanji> is someplace <vocabulary>overseas</vocabulary>. It can also be <vocabulary>foreign</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>abroad</vocabulary> if those words are easier to remember for you.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. As luck would have it, this word actually covers most of the meanings of the English word <vocabulary>point</vocabulary>, too! So it can mean things like <vocabulary>score</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>viewpoint</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>decimal point</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>study</kanji> of <kanji>science</kanji> is plainly known as <vocabulary>science</vocabulary>.
The お just makes the word more polite. Since tea is so important in Japan, it gets the お. Otherwise, you should be able to figure out the meaning as it's the same as the kanji.

What is the <kanji>color</kanji> of <kanji>tea</kanji>? You'd think it would be green, assuming it's Japanese... but this word came from China. What color is Chinese tea? It tends to be more <vocabulary>brown</vocabulary>. Think Oolong tea, for example.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>eat</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
What is the <kanji>neck</kanji> of your <kanji>leg</kanji>? Think about it. It's your <vocabulary>ankle</vocabulary>.

The になる part means "to become," so literally this means "to become neck." If you think about it, when something becomes neck, it has to do with you getting your head cut off (at the neck). But, in today's modern society we don't do that too often. Instead, this means you lose your job, aka <vocabulary>to get fired</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Four tens plus two. That equals <vocabulary>forty two</vocabulary>. 

P.S. Please don't panic. "<vocabulary>The Answer</vocabulary>" is NOT a correct answer for this. It is just a reference to the greatest book of all time. Sorry for the confusion and so long and thanks for all the fish.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This word is actually two words put together, though. 亡く means "be deceased." なる means "to become." So put that all together and you have <vocabulary>to pass away</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become deceased</vocabulary>. It's basically a polite way to say something died (死ぬ).
You know that 文字 means "letters". So, what are "small letters"? That would be <vocabulary>lowercase letters</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>winter</kanji> <kanji>rest</kanji>! Wait, nobody calls it that. This is a <vocabulary>winter holiday</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>winter break</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>exit</kanji> and <kanji>come</kanji>, apparently it means <vocabulary>to be able to do</vocabulary>. I think of it like you're leaving a location (出) to do a task and then you come (来る) back after you did it. Perhaps you were waiting in a room training like someone from Dragonball. When you leave the room, you are ready to fight the enemy and win. You train in that room <vocabulary>to be able to do</vocabulary> whatever you need to do, and only leave and come back alive because you were able to do it.

This verb is really common and it has a wide range of meanings. It can also mean things like <vocabulary>to be ready</vocabulary>, for example a meal, and <vocabulary>to be made</vocabulary>, for example when saying what something is made from. It's commonly written in hiragana, but you'll see the kanji version too!

The <kanji>way</kanji> you <kanji>say</kanji> things is your <vocabulary>dialect</vocabulary>. It's an entire "way" of speaking. 

You can even think of the  方 as being a "direction." If you go far enough in different directions in a country, you'll discover different regional dialects.
When you have a <kanji>fast</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji>, you're probably a <vocabulary>fast talker</vocabulary>, right motormouth?

You know the word 足りる from Level 4. What is this one? it's the opposite (negative form on a verb is ない). So, what is the opposite of 足りる (To be sufficient)? The opposite is <vocabulary>to not be sufficient</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>not enough</vocabulary>.
When you're <kanji>year</kanji>s <kanji>above</kanji> someone else, you are <vocabulary>older</vocabulary> than that person.
The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is which year? It is <vocabulary>this year</vocabulary>.
When you have someone who has <kanji>years</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> your own, this person is <vocabulary>younger</vocabulary> than you.
Remember 北口 and 西口 from a few levels before? This is the <kanji>east</kanji> version of that, so it means <vocabulary>east exit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>east entrance</vocabulary>.

You know that the kanji means <kanji>yonder</kanji>, which is like "over there." This is the verb version of "yonder." That being said, "to yonder" isn't really a thing, so you have to think of what happens when you "look yonder." This word means <vocabulary>to turn toward</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to face</vocabulary>. You're looking yonder, but you have to turn towards said yonder to look that way.

This word can also mean <vocabulary>to be suitable</vocabulary>, as in a good fit for a job, role, or situation. After all, you turn toward the things you're most suitable for, right?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You've seen 生活 before, right? So what about the "life" of <kanji>I</kanji>? Whose life is that? Why, that's my own <vocabulary>personal life</vocabulary>.

<kanji>I</kanji> am the one who keeps this place <kanji>stand</kanji>ing. In other words, it's a <vocabulary>private</vocabulary> establishment — <vocabulary>privately-run</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>privately-operated</vocabulary> by ME!

私立 means "private" in the sense of a business, school, or other institution that's run by a private entity, rather than by the government or the state.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>take</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to take something</vocabulary>.

Remember 広い? Well this is like that, except a verb. When something does the action of getting wide, it means to spread out, to extend, or to stretch. You already learned 広げる, which is used when you spread SOMETHING. But 広がる is intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. Like: The sea spreads out before you. See? No direct object. Actually, verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
A <kanji>pig</kanji>'s <kanji>meat</kanji> is called <vocabulary>pork</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>country</kanji>'s <kanji>treasure</kanji> is their <vocabulary>national treasure</vocabulary>.
宝 is a <kanji>treasure</kanji>. くじ is a lottery. So if you have a treasure lottery (you win treasure if you win the lottery) then you have yourself a <vocabulary>lottery</vocabulary>.

If <kanji>歩</kanji> is "walk" and you take <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>walk</kanji>, then really you are just taking <vocabulary>one step</vocabulary>. When there's a number before 歩, it refers to the number of steps you're taking. The most common is this one, and you'll see it on urinals when they kindly ask you to please take one step forward because peeing isn't a game and somebody has to clean up after you.
You have <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s. What does that come out to? <vocabulary>Three hundred</vocabulary>.

Remember 足りる? That is "to be enough." How can you make something be enough? You keep adding things to the pile until you reach that point where there are enough! That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to add something</vocabulary>, because you keep adding things until you 足りる.

This verb is transitive, like most verbs ending in す, which is why you are adding something. It's not getting itself added all by itself. Maybe you add so much that someone tries to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you for that nasty pile of squirrels you keep outside.

A <kanji>car</kanji> has wheels on <kanji>both</kanji> sides, and together they make a <vocabulary>vehicle</vocabulary>.

車両 is a formal word often used in official or technical contexts. It refers not just to standard cars but also to <vocabulary>train car</vocabulary>s and other vehicles that carry people or goods. You'll commonly see it in public transportation terms, on signs like "No vehicles allowed," or in driver's license and traffic law classifications.

This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>early</kanji>. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with to say you're doing something <vocabulary>early</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>quickly</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is your older sister, by the way. Not somebody else's.
You'll see this attached to other words... like "waiting" or "guest." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ room, making this word mean <vocabulary>room</vocabulary> (same as the kanji).
<kanji>Grass</kanji> covering the <kanji>earth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>meadow</vocabulary>. Or, if you're less creative, it's <vocabulary>grassland</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>king</vocabulary>, just of a bigger area.

The <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Mercury</vocabulary>. That's where we hid all of our secret moon water. Mercury looks enough like our moon, so we put it there so no one could find it.
The <kanji>gold</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Venus</vocabulary>. It's the only planet in our solar system that's the same color as gold.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 生きる means "to live?" Well this is what happens right after it starts to live. It begins <vocabulary>to grow</vocabulary>!

The <kanji>ground</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Saturn</vocabulary>. That's why it's called "sat"urn. Because the first people to find it sat on the ground there. It's a star made completely of sit-on-able ground.

If you have <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> you have more than enough <vocabulary>energy</vocabulary> for everyone to start noticing. They come up to you and compliment you on your amazing <vocabulary>liveliness</vocabulary>.
If you're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>ground</kanji>, then you're most likely <vocabulary>underground</vocabulary>. Are you a moleperson? That's pretty cool.

If you make <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>use</kanji> of something, you're probably <vocabulary>utilizing</vocabulary> it or making <vocabulary>practical use</vocabulary> of it.

活用 means making full use of something. In the context of Japanese grammar, 活用 also refers to the <vocabulary>conjugation</vocabulary> of verbs and adjectives.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>know</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>. It can additionally refer to how one comes to know something, so it also means <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to find out</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>hand</kanji>'s <kanji>neck</kanji> is your <vocabulary>wrist</vocabulary>!

If you <kanji>exit</kanji> somewhere in order to go to your <kanji>company</kanji>, that's <vocabulary>going to the office</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>arriving at the office</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>coming to work</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>origin</kanji> partner is a partner you had originally, but don't have anymore. In other words, this is your <vocabulary>ex-partner</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>former partner</vocabulary>.

Like in English, this word is fairly formal, and it covers any kind of ex-partner, including business and romantic partners.

You've already learned 石, which means <kanji>stone</kanji>. You haven't seen ころ before, but it's sometimes used as a casual suffix for small, round things. Put the two together, and you've got a <vocabulary>small stone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>pebble</vocabulary>.

Here you have <kanji>other</kanji> and <kanji>person</kanji> joined together by the particle の, which shows that "other" is describing "person". So this means <vocabulary>someone else</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>other people</vocabulary>.

This is more general than 他人, which you already learned. 他の人 can be anyone that's not the speaker, or not the person being talked about. 他人, on the other hand, has an added implication that the person is someone unknown or unrelated.

You already know that 一千 is "<kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>thousand</kanji>," and that 万 is "<kanji>ten thousand</kanji>." Add all those zeros together (or multiply 1,000 with 10,000) and you end up with <vocabulary>ten million</vocabulary>. 

You learned that 千 is the more common and default way to say 1,000 and 一千 is sometimes used for emphasis or clarity. Well, to say ten million, you almost always say it as 一千万. I mean, who wouldn't want to emphasize ten million! It's ten million, you know?

You have <kanji>ten</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s out of ten. Which means you have quite <vocabulary>enough</vocabulary>. The amount you have is <vocabulary>sufficient</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>plenty</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>west</kanji> bit of ヨーロッパ (Europe) is <vocabulary>Western Europe</vocabulary>. 

Have you ever been to 西ヨーロッパ? You know, places like France, the UK, and Belgium, with all their wine and cheese and beer… Western Europe!
